Literature Review: The structure and governance of global supply chains have garnered significant attention in recent years, with a growing body of literature exploring the impact of supply chain governance on social and environmental outcomes. However, existing research has primarily focused on the transnational firm, neglecting the complex interactions between local, national, and global actors and institutions that shape outcomes at the local level. This literature review aims to provide an overview of the dominant approaches to supply chain governance and identify opportunities for a more nuanced, multi-actor and multi-level analysis of social and environmental consequences of networked production.
